MOSAIC RIVERVIEW

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



Mosaic Fertilizer, LLC is committed to operate processes in a manner that is safe for all employees, community, and environment. Mosaic has established a process safety management system to ensure safe operation of the processes at the Riverview facility.

The risk management program (RMP) aids in the management of risks involved with the presence of hazardous substances at the Riverview. The RMP complies with the requirements of the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) 40 CFR 68, Accidental Release. One of the requirements of the RMP rule is to include an executive summary in the RMP describing the program in place at Mosaic. This document is intended to satisfy the executive summary.



RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN

The Riverview risk management program consists of three elements:

1.A hazard assessment designed to identify the potential offsite consequences of hypothetical accidental releases and accidents that have occurred during the last 5 years associated with the substances regulated by the RMP rule.

2.A prevention program to help maintain and safely operate processes containing significant quantities of substances regulated by the RMP rule.

3.An emergency response program to help respond to accidental releases of regulated substances from processes covered by the RMP rule. 

Information: The risk management program helps ensure that the Riverview is maintained and operated in a safe manner. The comprehensive safety program in place, establishes many levels of safeguards against accidental releases and injuries and damage that could potentially occur.



LIMITING THE USE OF HAZARDOUS SUBSTANCES

Before hazardous substances are incorporated in Mosaic processes, consideration is given to alternative products that are less hazardous. 

When a hazardous substance is the only choice, consideration is given to the potential adverse effects to employees, the public, and environmental. Prevention measures are implemented to reduce e

xposure. 



PREVENTING RELEASES OF THE HAZARDOUS SUBSTANCES USED AT THE FACILITY

Equipment utilized to hold or contain hazardous material, is designed, built, maintained and operated in a manner that reduces the likelihood of an accidental release. 

Industry standards and governmental regulations are closely adhered during the design, construction, and operation of the equipment.



LIMITING DAMAGE FROM A RELEASE, IF SUCH A RELEASE OCCURS

Riverview takes action to prevent accidental releases from occurring. The workforce is trained to recognize accidental releases, quickly assess the severity of a release, and to mitigate or stop the release.  Riverview works closely with the Riverview and Hillsborough County Fire Departments, and the local Emergency Planning Committee to ensure appropriate plans are in place to minimize the impact to employees, the community and environmental by of the release of any hazardous material. The Riverview safety program consists of a number of elements, some of which are required by the RMP rule. 

The RMP is primarily intended to describe those parts of the safety program required by the RMP rule.



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

We are committed to the safety of workers and the public, and the preservation of the environment, through the prevention of accidental releases of hazardous substances. 

We take reasonable steps to prevent foreseeable releases of hazardous substances. These steps include: 



TRAINING PROGRAMS FOR PERSONNEL

Programs to help ensure safety in the design, installation, operation, and maintenance of our processes, and Programs to evaluate the hazards of our processes.

In the event of an accidental release, Riverview strives to control and contain the release in a manner that will be safe for employees and mitigate injury to the public or damage to the environment.

Riverview provides emergency response training to our employees so that they are well prepared to handle emerg

ency situations and execute emergency response actions.



STATIONARY SOURCE & REGULATED SUBSTANCE ABOVE TQ ON SITE

Anhydrous ammonia, a regulated hazardous substance is utilized at the Riverview facility. The hazardous properties of ammonia make it necessary to observe safety precautions during handling in order to:

Prevent unnecessary human exposure

Reduce the threat to facility personnel 

Reduce the threat to the community and the environment

At the Riverview facility, ammonia storage exceeds the threshold quantity of 10,000 lbs.

Ammonia is used as a raw material at the Riverview. Ammonia as liquefied gas is stored in tanks. The ammonia is piped to the monoammonium phosphate (MAP) and Diammonium phosphate (DAP) plants. Liquefied or gaseous ammonia may pose a health risk if the compressors, containers, or lines transferring the ammonia develop leaks or rupture. Ammonia is transported into the facility via the Tampa Bay Pipeline and is stored in four storage vessels (bullets). The capacity of each bullet is 200 tons. Administrative controls at the facility limit the quantity of ammonia stored in each bullet to 175 tons.



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL - SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

At Mosaic, safety is the highest priority. Beginning in 1992, Mosaic incorporated this belief into a prevention program that complies with the Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) process safety management (PSM) regulation. 

For Mosaic, the prevention program requirements of EPA's RMP rule are nearly identical to the PSM regulation. 

The following sections briefly describe the elements of our prevention program that address the RMP rule requirements.

The Site accident prevention program consists of the following 12 elements:



PROCESS SAFETY INFORMATION

Mosaic maintains a variety of technical documents, including an emergency preparedness plan, to ensure that employees and local emergency responders are award of the hazards associated with

the Riverview facility. These documents address the following:

Physical properties of the hazardous substances at the facility

Operating parameters for our equipment

Design basis and configuration for our equipment. 

Riverview ensures that this process safety information is available to all employees.

Process Hazard Analysis

The site performs and periodically updates process hazard analyses to identify hazards and make recommendations to ensure safe operation.

A multidisciplinary team is assembled to analyze the hazards of processes. This team includes personnel with engineering and process operating experience and a leader with process hazard analysis experience. The team systematically addresses the hazards associated with operation of the equipment in the process areas. The team prepares a written report describing the results of the analysis, including a list of recommendations. 

Responsibility for resolving the recommendations is assigned to area personnel, and, when appropriate, changes to enhance Operating Procedures

Operators and managers work together to develop and maintain operating procedures and to define how tasks related to process operations should be safely performed. 

The operating procedures are utilized to train employees and serve as reference guides detailing actions to take during normal operations and process upsets. Operating procedures include:

Steps for safely conducting activities

Applicable process safety information, such as safe operating limits and consequences of process deviations

Safety and health considerations, such as chemical hazards, personal protective equipment requirements, and actions to take if exposure to a hazardous substance occurs



TRAINING

Employees are trained to safely and effectively perform assigned tasks. The training program includes both initial and refresher training that covers the following:

A general overview of the process, 

The properties and hazards of the substances in the process, a

nd 

A detailed review of the process operating procedures and safe work practices. Written, oral and skill demonstration reviews are used to verify that an employee understands the training material.



MECHANICAL INTEGRITY

Process equipment is maintained in order to prevent failures that could endanger employees, the public, or the environment. Our mechanical integrity (preventive maintenance) program includes the following:

An inspection and testing program to help identify equipment deterioration and damage before the equipment fails and 

A quality assurance function to help ensure that new and replacement equipment meet the strict design standards required for service in our processes.



MANAGEMENT OF CHANGE

All proposed changes to chemicals, equipment, technology, and procedures are evaluated in order to ensure that the change does not negatively affect safe operations. All changes other than replacement-in-kind (e.g., replacing a valve with an identical valve) must be approved through the full management of change program. This ensures the following:

Inadvertent consequences of process changes are prevented

Safety consequences of changes are addressed

Affected process safety information and procedures are updated

Affected employees are notified of the changes.



PRE-STARTUP SAFETY REVIEW

New or recently modified processes are historically more likely to be involved in accidental releases. In order to circumvent these occurrences, safety reviews are performed prior to placing them into service. 

This review confirms that:

Construction and equipment are in accordance with design specifications

Adequate safety, operating, maintenance, and emergency procedures are in place

Employee training has been completed

For a covered process, a process hazard analysis has been performed if the process is new, or

Management of change requirements have been completed if an existing process has been modified



COMPLIANCE AUDIT

The foundation of an effective

prevention program is a regular comprehensive assessment. 

Every 3 years a compliance audit is performed to verify that the prevention program in place is effective and addresses safety issues. 

Mosaic Corporate Compliance Assurance assembles an audit team that includes personnel knowledgeable in the PSM and RMP regulations and process design.

The Assurance team evaluates the prevention program to determine if it meets the requirements of OSHA 29 CFR 1910.119 and 40 CFR Part 68. 

The results of the audit are documented, action items are generated, and appropriate enhancements to the prevention program are implemented.



INCIDENT INVESTIGATION

Riverview investigates incidents that could reasonably have resulted in serious injury to personnel, the public, or the environment so that similar incidents can be prevented in the future. 

Employees receive training on how to identify and report incidents requiring investigation. 

When an incident occurs, the following steps are taken:

Investigation team is assembled

Investigation is initiated within 48 hours of the incident

The results of the investigation are documented

Appropriate process improvements are implemented



EMPLOYEE PARTICIPATION

Riverview has developed a written employee participation program for covered processes to ensure that the safety concerns of employees are addressed. 

Employees are encouraged to actively participate in the prevention program 



HOT WORK PERMITS

The hot work permit program was developed to control spark or flame producing activities that could result in fires or explosions. During development the OSHA fire prevention and protection requirements were reviewed and a hot work permit form was created in order to comply with these requirements.

Employees who perform hot work are required to complete the form and the appropriate supervisor reviews the completed form and work area before work can begin. 

Training on hot work activities and on the requirements of the hot wor

k permit program is included in the site safe work practices orientation and annual refresher training.



CONTRACTORS

A Contractor Management program is in place to ensure that contractor activities are performed in a safe manner. 

Contract supervisors are made aware of the hazards of all processes that contractors are assigned to as well as safe work practices, and emergency response procedures. 

Contractors are required to ensure that training has been performed for all employees prior to beginning work at the Riverview facility. Contractor training is updated annually for each employee.



CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

In addition to the required prevention program elements, special measures and safety features specific to ammonia have been implemented at Mosaic to prevent accidents or releases. 

The ammonia bullets on site are visually inspected monthly and tested for thickness at appropriate intervals. The valves on the ammonia bullets piping are designed and maintained in accordance with good engineering practices established by the American Petroleum Institute (API) and American Society of Mechanical Engineers (ASME). 

All ammonia lines transferring liquid or gaseous product are inspected for mechanical integrity at regular frequencies. 

All ammonia pressure relief valves are also maintained per API and ASME good engineering practices. Preventive maintenance is performed on all process equipment to ensure continuous operation without incident. 

Mosaic maintains an ammonia relief vent flare system that contains a self-igniter and is able to be run on an alternative fuel should a natural gas failure occur. These are just some of the measures which help Mosaic safeguard the employees, public, and the environment.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAMS

Riverview has established a written emergency response program to help ensure the safety of personnel who respond to accidental releases of hazardous substances. The emergency response plan includes procedur

es for:

Informing the Riverview Fire Department, the Florida EPA/FDEP, the Hillsborough County Local Emergency Planning Committee, and the National Spill Response Center about accidental releases that could reasonably result in offsite consequences

Providing proper first aid and emergency medical treatment for accidental human exposure to hazardous substances

Obtaining outside assistance to control and contain accidental releases of hazardous substances, including the use of emergency response equipment



REVIEWING AND UPDATING THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN 

Employees are trained to recognize and report emergency situations. Personnel are trained in evacuation procedures. The Hillsborough County Emergency Management Agency is responsible for notifying the public of emergency situations, when necessary.

The written emergency response plan complies with other federal contingency plan regulations [e.g. OSHA regulation 29 CFR 1910.38(a) and 1910.120(q)], a copy of the plan has been provided to the fire department. Also, a Hillsborough County Emergency Operations Plan has been developed by the Local Emergency Planning Committee, of which a Mosaic representative is a member.



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Riverview constantly strives to improve the safety of processes using the following:

A program soliciting safety suggestions from our employees 

Weekly safety walk through reports

All recommendations received by plant management are evaluated and implemented when safety can be improved. 

An annual review of all operating ensures that they are correct, Training is provided to employees and contractors on a wide variety of safety and operating topics. 



The Mosaic Fertilizer plant in Riverview Florida, is constantly being modified as new and improved equipment is placed in service. This ensures that a very high standard of safety is maintained facility wide.
